question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
When I was studying Economics in Delhi University, Ritu was senior than me.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.29_18-Oct_Shift-3)
option_4: When I was studying Economics
solution:
Answer: senior than me

Explanation:
The phrase "senior than me" is incorrect.

  • The correct comparative structure is "senior to me."

  • "Than" is used with comparatives like bigger, taller, but "senior" pairs with "to."

Correct sentence:
"When I was studying Economics in Delhi University, Ritu was senior to me."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
This boy performed / extremely good / in the / dance competition.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.32_21-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: extremely good

Explanation:

  • The phrase "extremely good" is incorrect because "good" is an adjective, but here an adverb is needed to describe how the boy performed.

  • The correct phrase should be "extremely well" since "well" is the adverb form used to describe actions.

  • Other segments are grammatically correct.

Correct sentence:
"This boy performed extremely well in the dance competition."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains a grammatical error.
Ms. Malathi is old much to join a college now.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.33_22-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: old much

Explanation:
The phrase "old much" is grammatically incorrect. The correct form should be "too old" when expressing that someone’s age prevents them from doing something.

Correct sentence:
"Ms. Malathi is too old to join a college now."

Other parts:

  • "Ms. Malathi is" – correct

  • "to join" – correct

  • "a college now" – correct

Hence, "old much" is the part containing the error.

question:
The given sentence has an error. Select the option that rectifies the error.
The students were asked to turn up their assignments by Friday.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.34_22-Oct_Shift-2)
option_2: asked turn up their assignments
solution:
Answer: turn in their assignments

Explanation:
The correct phrasal verb for submitting assignments is "turn in," not "turn up."

  • Turn in means to submit or hand over work.

  • Turn up means to appear or arrive, which is incorrect here.

Correct sentence:
"The students were asked to turn in their assignments by Friday."

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains an error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options. Select the correct alternative.
When they left for Mexico, their house was in g̲o̲o̲d̲ condition than it is now.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.36_23-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer:better

Explanation:
The sentence is making a comparison between two points in time — when they left for Mexico and now.
When comparing two things, we use the comparative form of adjectives.

  • The word "good" becomes "better" in the comparative form.

  • Saying "in good condition than..." is incorrect — it should be "in better condition than..."

Let’s review the options:

  • better → ✅ Correct comparative form of "good"

  • excellent → ❌ Not a comparative; also not used with "than"

  • more good → ❌ Incorrect (never use "more" with "good"; use "better")

  • best → ❌ Superlative form, used when comparing more than two

Correct sentence:
When they left for Mexico, their house was in better condition than it is now.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The train is running / late by six hours / so it / cannot make over the time.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.37_23-Oct_Shift-2)
option_4: cannot make over the time
solution:
Answer:cannot make over the time

Explanation:
The error lies in the incorrect use of the phrasal verb "make over."

  • "Make over" means to transfer ownership (like property or money), which doesn't fit here.

  • The correct phrase should be "make up the time," which means to compensate for lost time (खोए हुए समय की भरपाई करना).

Correct sentence:
The train is running late by six hours, so it cannot make up the time.

Difficult Phrase Meaning:

  • Make up the time – to recover or compensate for lost time (समय की भरपाई करना)

question:
The following sentence has been split into segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
He missed the college bus / because he woke up / unpardonably lately in the morning.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.39_28-Oct_Shift-1)
option_1: he missed the college bus
option_2: unpardonably lately in the morning
solution:
Answer:unpardonably lately in the morning

Explanation:
The error lies in the phrase "unpardonably lately".
The word "lately" means recently (हाल ही में), which does not fit the context of waking up late on a specific morning.

The correct word should be "late", and the correct adverb form for how he woke up is "unpardonably late" – अक्षम्य रूप से देर से.

Let’s correct the sentence:
He missed the college bus because he woke up unpardonably late in the morning.

So, the error is in the segment "unpardonably lately in the morning".

question:
The following sentence contains an error. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
The robbers stabbed him by a sharp knife and he started bleeding profusely on the spot.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.40_28-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer:with a sharp knife

Explanation:
The error in the sentence is in the phrase "stabbed him by a sharp knife". The correct preposition to use with "stab" is "with", not "by".

  • "Stab with a knife" is the correct and standard usage.

  • "By" is used to indicate the agent (e.g., stabbed by someone), not the instrument.

Let’s correct the sentence:
The robbers stabbed him with a sharp knife and he started bleeding profusely on the spot.

  • Profusely – in large amounts or quantities – अत्यधिक / बहुत अधिक

question:
Select the sentence that has a grammatical error.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.41_28-Oct_Shift-3)
option_1: It was a huge zoo with an elephant enclosure.
option_2: He was an honest engineer by profession.
option_3: Alka bought new pair of shoes for the party.
option_4: Suhas has a younger brother and an elder sister.
solution:
Answer:Alka bought new pair of shoes for the party.

Explanation:
The error is in the article usage before "pair". Since "pair" is a singular countable noun, it must be preceded by "a" or "a new", not just "new."

Incorrect: Alka bought new pair of shoes
Correct: Alka bought a new pair of shoes

Let’s check the other sentences:

  • It was a huge zoo with an elephant enclosure. → ✅ Correct

  • He was an honest engineer by profession. → ✅ "An" is correctly used before a vowel sound ("honest")

  • Suhas has a younger brother and an elder sister. → ✅ Correct

Corrected sentence:
Alka bought a new pair of shoes for the party.

question:
Select the sentence that has a grammatical error.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.45_30-Oct_Shift-1)
option_1: The company came up with a brilliant marketing strategy.
option_2: We came in the meeting room quietly.
option_3: She always comes down with a cold in winter.
option_4: He came across an interesting article while researching.
solution:
Answer:We came in the meeting room quietly.

Explanation:
The error lies in the incorrect use of the preposition "in". The correct preposition is "into", because we are referring to movement towards the inside of the meeting room.

  • "Come into" is used for entering a space.

  • "Come in" is often used when the person is already at the threshold or when giving permission, like "Come in!"

Correct sentence:
We came into the meeting room quietly.

All the other sentences are grammatically correct.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
My mother said / that the thief / Ramesh will learnt / his lesson soon.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.46_30-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: c) Ramesh will learnt

Explanation:
The error lies in the phrase "will learnt", which is grammatically incorrect.
After "will", we always use the base form of the verb (first form), not the past participle.

  • Learnt = past participle of learn (सीखा)

  • Correct form: "Ramesh will learn"

So, the correct sentence should be:
"My mother said that the thief Ramesh will learn his lesson soon."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The fresh air / in the garden relaxes / the minds of children as / the environment is cleaner.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.49_04-Nov_Shift-2)
option_3: the minds of children as
solution:
Correct Answer: d) the environment is cleaner

Explanation:
The error lies in the phrase "the environment is cleaner."
The sentence talks about how fresh air in the garden relaxes children, implying a general truth or repeated action — so the sentence should maintain the present simple tense throughout.

However, the phrase "the environment is cleaner" uses comparative form "cleaner", which is inappropriate unless it's comparing two environments.

To correct it, the sentence should read:
"The fresh air in the garden relaxes the minds of children as the environment is clean."

  • Cleaner = comparative (ज़्यादा साफ़), used when comparing

  • Clean = correct positive form for a general statement (साफ़)

So, the grammatical error is in "the environment is cleaner" → it should be "the environment is clean."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
An eucalyptus tree in my backyard acts as a landmark for many to reach my house.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.49_04-Nov_Shift-2)
option_1: acts as a landmark for many
solution:
Answer: b) An eucalyptus tree

Explanation:
The error is in the phrase "An eucalyptus tree".

  • The correct article is "A", not "An", because "eucalyptus" begins with a consonant sound (it sounds like "you-calyptus", not "eh-calyptus").

Correct phrase:"A eucalyptus tree"

Correct sentence:
"A eucalyptus tree in my backyard acts as a landmark for many to reach my house."

question:
Read the sentence given below and identify if there is an error in it. The error can be in any segment of the sentence which are marked A, B, C, and D. Select option D if there is 'No error'.
(A) Ritika angrily / (B) spoke to Kartik / (C) after the meeting / (D) No error.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.5_01-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct answer:D (No error)

Explanation:

Let’s examine each part of the sentence:

  • (A) Ritika angrily – ✅ grammatically correct; "angrily" is an adverb modifying the verb "spoke"

  • (B) spoke to Kartik – ✅ correct verb usage; "spoke to" is the right prepositional phrase

  • (C) after the meeting – ✅ correctly placed time expression

  • (D) No error – ✔️ since all parts are grammatically and structurally correct

So, the sentence is error-free, and the correct answer is D (No error).

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
She oftenly goes / shopping with / her friends / on Saturdays.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.53_05-Nov_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: a) She oftenly goes

Explanation:
The word "oftenly" is incorrect. The correct adverb is "often" (अक्सर).

  • Often does not take the suffix "-ly."

Correct sentence: "She often goes shopping with her friends on Saturdays."

All other segments are grammatically correct.

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains as error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options. Select the correct alternative.
They had a l̲e̲a̲s̲t̲ celebration on her birthday.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.55_11-Nov_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: little

Explanation:
The word "little" means a small amount of something (थोड़ा सा).
It is used correctly here because "celebration" is an uncountable noun, and "little" fits when talking about a small amount of it.
So, "They had little celebration on her birthday" means the celebration was very small or minimal.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
If I wrote an email / to my boss now, / he will react / by yelling at me tomorrow in the morning.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.56_11-Nov_Shift-3)
option_2: If I wrote an email
option_3: by yelling at me tomorrow in the morning.
solution:
Answer: If I wrote an email

Explanation:
In conditional sentences about present or future situations, we use:

  • If + present tense, then will + verb (First Conditional)
    The phrase "If I wrote an email" incorrectly uses the past tense "wrote" with "will" in the result clause.

Correct form:
"If I write an email to my boss now, he will react..."

Other parts are grammatically correct.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
My sister performed / brilliant / in the competition / yesterday.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.57_12-Nov_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: brilliant

Explanation:
The word "brilliant" is an adjective and should not be used to describe how someone performed. The correct adverb form is "brilliantly" (शानदार तरीके से).

Correct sentence:
"My sister performed brilliantly in the competition yesterday."

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains as error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options. Select the correct alternative.
Pankaj is a b̲e̲t̲t̲e̲r̲ cook.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.59_12-Nov_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: good

Explanation:
The correct positive form is "good".

  • Better is the comparative form of good, so we cannot say "Pankaj is a better cook" without a comparison.

  • If no comparison is needed, simply say "Pankaj is a good cook."

  • Other options:

  • More good is incorrect.

  • Best is superlative, meaning the highest degree.

  • Goodest is not a word.

Correct sentence: "Pankaj is a good cook."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I still / do not understand / why he did not / reply my email.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.59_12-Nov_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: d) reply my email

Explanation:
The verb "reply" should be followed by the preposition "to" when referring to an email or message.
Correct phrase: "reply to my email."
Other parts of the sentence are grammatically correct.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
He is waiting / at airport to receive / Mr. Smith, who is / coming from South Africa.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.6_07-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct answer:at airport to receive

Explanation:

The phrase "at airport" is missing the article"the" before a specific place.

  • When referring to specific locations like "the airport", "the hospital", etc., we use the definite article "the."

Correct phrase: "at the airport to receive"

Let’s review the segments:

  • He is waiting – ✅ correct

  • At airport to receive – ❌ incorrect; should be "at the airport to receive"

  • Mr. Smith, who is – ✅ grammatically correct

  • Coming from South Africa. – ✅ correct

Correct sentence:
"He is waiting at the airport to receive Mr. Smith, who is coming from South Africa."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains anerror in phrasal verb.
Tina dropped behind of / college and / went straight / into a good job.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.6_07-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct answer:Tina dropped behind of

Explanation:

The phrasal verb "drop behind" means to fall behind in progress, especially in studies or work. However, it is not followed by "of."

Correct usage: "drop behind in (something)"
For example: She dropped behind in her studies.

Let’s break down the error:

  • "Dropped behind of" – ❌ incorrect; "of" should not follow the phrasal verb "drop behind"

  • Correct form would be: "Tina dropped out of college..." if the intended meaning is she left college

  • If the meaning is she fell behind academically, it should be: "dropped behind in college"

But since she "went straight into a good job," the intended meaning is that she left college, so the correct phrasal verb is:
"dropped out of college"

Correct sentence:
"Tina dropped out of college and went straight into a good job."

Therefore, the segment "Tina dropped behind of" contains the error.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Dr. Oppenheimer is the exceptional movie of all the movies in recent times.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.60_13-Nov_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: a) the exceptional movie

Explanation:
The phrase "the exceptional movie" is incorrect here because "exceptional" means outstanding or unusual, which is an adjective, but the sentence context is likely trying to say it is the best or most outstanding movie.
More importantly, the phrase should be "the most exceptional movie" to compare among all movies.
Without "most," it sounds incomplete for a superlative comparison.

Other parts of the sentence are grammatically correct.

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains an error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options.
Select the correct alternative.
Poverty is the u̲r̲g̲e̲n̲t̲ concern in India today.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.61_13-Nov_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: most urgent

Explanation:
The correct superlative form of "urgent" is "most urgent" (सबसे आवश्यक).

  • More urgent is comparative, used when comparing two things.

  • Urgentest and urgenter are incorrect and not valid English words.

So, "most urgent" correctly replaces "urgent" to express the highest degree of concern.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Manoj has a bigger / farmhouse of one hundred / hectares near the city.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.61_13-Nov_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: Manoj has a bigger

Explanation:
The error is in "Manoj has a bigger" because "bigger" is a comparative adjective and needs a comparison with something else.
The sentence should say:

  • "Manoj has the biggest farmhouse..." if emphasizing the largest, or

  • "Manoj has a bigger farmhouse than..." if comparing with another farmhouse.

Since no comparison is given, "bigger" is incorrect here.

Other parts of the sentence are correct.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The car which I bought last year was cheap than my bike.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.62_13-Nov_Shift-3)
option_4: was cheap than my bike
solution:
Answer: was cheap than my bike

Explanation:
The error is in the phrase "was cheap than my bike."

  • The correct comparative form is "was cheaper than my bike."

  • Cheap is the base adjective; for comparison, we use cheaper.

Other parts of the sentence are correct.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four parts. Identify the part that contains a grammatical error.
Surprisingly!/ dark chocolates/ are most bitterer/ in taste.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.64_14-Nov_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: are most bitterer

Explanation:
The phrase "most bitterer" is incorrect because it uses both the superlative "most" and the comparative suffix "-er" together, which is redundant.

  • Correct forms:
     • "more bitter" (comparative)
     • "most bitter" (superlative)

Other parts of the sentence are correct.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
My cousin thinks that / English is difficult / than other subjects.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.65_14-Nov_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: English is difficult
Solution:

  • The sentence says: "English is difficult than other subjects."

  • This is incorrect because "than" is used after a comparative adjective, and "difficult" is a positive degree.

  • The correct comparative form of "difficult" is "more difficult".

  • So, the corrected sentence should be: "English is more difficult than other subjects."

  • Therefore, the error is in the part "English is difficult".

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains an error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options.
Select the correct alternative.
I want to buy the l̲e̲s̲s̲ expensive bike, but with the best mileage.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.8_07-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct answer: least

Explanation:

  • When comparing one item with all others in terms of having the smallest amount or degree, we use the superlative form.

  • The correct superlative of "less" is "least".

  • Lesser is comparative (used when comparing two things), not superlative.

  • Little is an adjective or adverb meaning small in amount, but not used here.

  • Most less is grammatically incorrect.

Correct sentence:
"I want to buy the least expensive bike, but with the best mileage."

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains as error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options. Select the correct alternative.
The sky appeared to be g̲r̲e̲y̲e̲s̲t̲ after the storm.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.9_08-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct answer: greyer

Explanation:

  • The underlined word "greyest" is the superlative form of grey.

  • The sentence compares the sky's color after the storm to its previous state, so the comparative form should be used, not the superlative.

  • Greyer is the correct comparative form.

  • Other options:

  • More grey – grammatically possible but less common than "greyer."

  • Most grey – incorrect comparative/superlative form.

  • Grey – positive form, no comparison.

Correct sentence:
"The sky appeared to be greyer after the storm."

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains as error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options. Select the correct alternative.
Playing in the field, the young g̲a̲y̲e̲r̲ students were laughing and giggling.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.9_08-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct answer: gay

Explanation:

  • The word "gayer" is the comparative form of "gay," used when comparing two things.

  • The sentence describes young gay students without any comparison, so the positive form "gay" should be used.

  • Other options:

  • most gay – incorrect comparative/superlative form

  • gayest – superlative form, used when comparing three or more things

  • more gay – awkward comparative, less common than "gayer"

Correct sentence:
"Playing in the field, the young gay students were laughing and giggling."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
I have three sisters: / Meera is the elder / and Charu is the youngest.

(SSC CHSL 2023 T-2 (10 Jan))
option_2: and Charu is the youngest
solution:
The part that contains the error is: Meera is the elder

The corrected sentence would be: I have three sisters: Meera is the eldest, and Charu is the youngest.

when comparing two individuals in terms of age or hierarchical order within a group, we use the terms "older" and "younger." However, when comparing among more than two individuals, especially in a group of siblings, we use the terms "oldest" and "youngest."

question:
There is an error in the given sentence. From the options given, identify the sentence that corrects the error to make it a grammatically accurate sentence.
This lesser known heritage building is so beautiful as the Red Fort.

(SSC CHSL 2023 T-2 (2 Nov))
option_1: This lesser known heritage building is as much beautiful as the Red Fort.
option_2: This lesser known heritage building is very much beautiful as the Red Fort.
option_3: This less known heritage building is much beautiful than the Red Fort.
option_4: This heritage building is as beautiful as the Red Fort.
solution:
Correction:

"This lesser-known heritage building is as much beautiful as the Red Fort."

Explanation:

The error in the original sentence is the use of "so beautiful as." The correct construction for making a comparison of beauty is "as much beautiful as."

question:
Parts of the given sentence have been underlined. One of them contains an error. The underlined parts are given as options with some changes. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
The f̲i̲l̲m̲ ̲r̲e̲c̲e̲i̲v̲e̲d̲ critical a̲c̲c̲l̲a̲i̲m̲ ̲f̲o̲r̲ being a̲ ̲m̲o̲r̲e̲ ̲i̲n̲n̲o̲v̲a̲t̲i̲v̲e̲ movie o̲f̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲y̲e̲a̲r̲.

(SSC CHSL 2023 T-2 (2 Nov))
solution:
The correct option that rectifies the error in the underlined parts of the sentence is: "The film received critical acclaim for being the most innovative movie of the year."

An innovative: The corrected sentence uses "the most innovative" to compare the film's innovation to others and make a superlative statement.

question:
The given sentence has an error. Choose the option that corrects the error
Throw a rounder stone to create ripples in the water.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-2 (26 Oct))
option_1: Throw a round stone to create ripples in the water.
option_2: Throw the roundest stone to create ripples in the water.
option_3: Throw a more rounder stone to create ripples in the water.
option_4: Throw a more round stone to create ripples in the water.
solution:
The correct answer is option a.

The error in the original sentence is the use of "rounder," which is not the correct comparative form of the adjective "round."

Hence, The correct sentence is: “Throw a round stone to create ripples in the water.”
